Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2012 02:16PM prairyk wrote: Hi Michelle. Well, it turned out I had an infection. Bleck. After the doctor drained and packed it, she ordered antibiotics. Now I'm getting back on track. I'm sorry to hear you're having more surgery. Take care of yourself. KayÂ
Posts.Title: Sore arm michellej1980 prairyk

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2012 10:15AM prairyk wrote: Michelle, this is my first post here, but since I have had the same problem and just got an explanation yesterday, I want to share. I had a lumphectomy and sentinel lymph node removal (forgive me—I don't know the jargon and acronyms yet) Aug. 30 and had to go back for re-incision to remove more cancer cells and tissue Sept. 6. Since the second surgery, my arm had been extremely sore and sensitive. I thought at first because I had so much adhesive from the dressing I could not get removed. My arm stuck to my body! But after working on that, the pain persisted. At the same time, the numbness I had been feeling was dissipating. Finally yesterday I was told it was because of the lymph node removal, to start with—but that usually starts 2-3 weeks after surgery. However, because the doctor had to re-incise, the tissue was all disturbed and angry; thus the earlier pain. It is normal, the nurse said. HOWEVER—and I don't want to scare you—please monitor it closely. Now I'm having redness around the incision, pressure (swelling) and seepage and I'm going back to see my doctor this afternoon. This latter is probably a totally different problem—but just want to tell you this so you can watch out. AND be assured the arm thing is normal. Good luck!
Posts.Title: Sore arm michellej1980 prairyk
